BNC000006_Part_A_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn this point display an accurate and complete comprehension of one result that Pliny hopes will come from his request to the addressee.

o.d:
The response does not display adequate comprehension of the passage or relevant part of it.

Question A (i): Identify one and only one obstacle to Pliny as he attempted to escape the situation.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “a conclusion about a difficult matter”

  • “Pliny hopes that the addressee will help Pliny by thinking about a certain matter carefully and offer his well-considered and definitive opinion on that matter.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Restate the prompt.

  • Display an inaccurate comprehension.

  • Display an incomplete comprehension.

The response displays an adequate comprehension of the passage or relevant part of it.

Question A (i): Identify one and only one obstacle to Pliny as he attempted to escape the situation.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “a conclusion about a difficult matter”

  • “Pliny hopes that the addressee will help Pliny by thinking about a certain matter carefully and offer his well-considered and definitive opinion on that matter.”

BNC000006_Part_A_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn this point provide Latin that fully and accurately supports the answer to Part A (i).

o.d:
The response does not provide Latin that adequately supports the answer to Part A (i).

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • disputes, ex altera tamen fortius

  • ne me suspensum incertumque dimittas

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Provide no Latin.

  • Provide Latin that does not support the answer to Part A (i).

  • Provide Latin that partially supports the answer to Part A (i).

The response provides Latin that adequately supports the answer to Part A (i).

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • disputes, ex altera tamen fortius

  • ne me suspensum incertumque dimittas

Additional Notes:

  • Parentheses indicate words that a response may but does not need to include in order to earn the point.

  • Responses can still earn the point for accurately supporting the answer to Part A (i) even if the answer to Part A (i) did not receive credit.

BNC000006_Part_A_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn this point provide an accurate and complete translation of the answer to Part A (ii).

o.d:
The response does not provide an accurate translation of the provided Latin.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “you should argue one side more strongly”

  • “so that you don’t leave me in suspense and uncertain”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Provide no translation.

  • Provide an inaccurate translation of the answer to Part A (ii).

  • Provide an incomplete translation of the answer to Part A (ii).

The response provides an accurate translation of the provided Latin.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “you should argue one side more strongly”

  • “so that you don’t leave me in suspense and uncertain”

Additional Notes:

  • Responses must correctly translate all required words to earn the point.

  • If additional Latin is provided for Part A (ii), the accuracy of the translation of this additional Latin does not affect the response’s score.

  • Responses can still earn the point for correctly translating the Latin in Part A (ii) even if the answer to Part A (ii) did not receive credit.

BNC000006_Part_B_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn this point present an interpretation that addresses how Pliny characterizes himself through his actions.

o.d:
The response does not present an interpretation that responds directly to the prompt.

Question B: In 3-4 complete sentences, identify one approach that Pliny takes to convince his addressee to do what he asks. Explain how the passage illustrates this approach.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny suggests that the recipient present their opinion by weighing both sides of the issue but emphasizing one side more strongly.”

  • “Pliny tries to persuade his addresse by showing that their knowledge and expertise are crucial to resolving his uncertainty.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Restates the prompt without responding to it.

  • Respond to a related but different prompt.

  • Do not respond to any single prompt.

The response presents an interpretation that responds directly to the prompt.

Question B: In 3-4 complete sentences, identify one approach that Pliny takes to convince his addressee to do what he asks. Explain how the passage illustrates this approach.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny suggests that the recipient present their opinion by weighing both sides of the issue but emphasizing one side more strongly.”

  • “Pliny tries to persuade his addresse by showing that their knowledge and expertise are crucial to resolving his uncertainty.”

Additional Notes:

  • The interpretation may be anywhere within the response.

  • An interpretation that meets the criteria can be awarded the point regardless of whether the provided Latin citations and explanations successfully support the interpretation.

BNC000006_Part_B_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Present a citation that exhibits a partially accurate understanding of the cited Latin.

  • Present a citation that, while not wholly inaccurate, contains significant errors and/or reflects a weak understanding of the Latin.

  • Present a citation that is no more substantive than a single Latin word or short phrase taken out of context.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Present a citation that exhibits an accurate understanding of the cited Latin.

  • Present a paraphrase or translation of cited Latin that may contain, at most, minor errors that do not detract from the response.

  • Present a citation that is more substantive than a single Latin word or a short phrase taken out of context.

o.d:
The response provides no Latin citation or one that is wholly incorrect from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny asks the reader to consider both sides of the argument but advocate more strongly for one (Licet etiam...tamen fortius).”

  • “Pliny asks for a decisive recommendation by stating that the purpose of consulting the addressee was to eliminate doubt (cum mihi consulendi causa fuerit, ut dubitare desinerem).”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Cite no Latin

  • Present a citation, but the citation exhibits no understanding of the Latin.

  • Present a citation, but the citation exhibits a complete misunderstanding of the Latin.

The response provides one partially correct Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny tells the reader that his issue has two sides to it (Licet etiam utramque in partem (ut soles) disputes).”

  • “Pliny states that he is not unworthy of receiving the reader's knowledge (ne ego...facias).”

Additional Notes:

  • Additional citations, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the one accurate citation.)

The response provides one correct Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny asks the reader to consider both sides of the argument but advocate more strongly for one (Licet etiam...tamen fortius).”

  • “Pliny asks for a decisive recommendation by stating that the purpose of consulting the addressee was to eliminate doubt (cum mihi consulendi causa fuerit, ut dubitare desinerem).”

Additional Notes:

  • Additional citations, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the one accurate citation.)

BNC000006_Part_B_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Provide an explanation of how the cited Latin relates to how Pliny characterizes himself through his actions.

  • Do not go beyond mere summary of the cited Latin in the explanation.

  • Display only limited understanding of the implied information in the Latin citation and/or make inaccurate inferences in the explanation.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Adequately and successfully explain how the citation from the provided Latin text relates to how Pliny characterizes himself through his actions.

  • Relate the cited Latin to the prompt with substantive and sufficiently persuasive analysis in the explanation.

o.d:
The response provides no explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny shows deference to the recipient’s method of reasoning by acknowledging their skill in presenting balanced arguments (utramque...fortius). By requesting that they advocate strongly for one side, Pliny relies on their judgment to help him resolve his uncertainty, demonstrating his trust in their intellectual authority.”

  • “Pliny expresses his trust in the recipient’s wisdom by requesting that they not leave him uncertain (ne me suspensum incertumque dimittas). This appeal to their responsibility and knowledge strengthens his persuasion by making the recipient feel compelled to provide a decisive answer.”

Responses that do not earn these points.

  • Provide no explanation of the cited Latin.

  • Do not address the prompt in the explanation.

  • Do not address the specific Latin citation in the explanation.

  • Rely on incorrect assumptions about the Latin citation in the explanation.

The response provides one incomplete explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny suggests that the reader should consider both sides of the issue (utram...disputes). This shows that Pliny respects their ability to weigh out arguments for complicated situations.”

  • “Pliny says that he trusts the reader's knowledge (eruditionem tuam intendas). This reflects Pliny's opinion that they are qualified to provide a strong response.”

Additional Notes:

The explanation does not need to be in separate sentences. The Latin citation and the explanation of it can be contained in a single sentence (or multiple sentences).

Provides one complete explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Pliny shows deference to the recipient’s method of reasoning by acknowledging their skill in presenting balanced arguments (utramque...fortius). By requesting that they advocate strongly for one side, Pliny relies on their judgment to help him resolve his uncertainty, demonstrating his trust in their intellectual authority.”

  • “Pliny expresses his trust in the recipient’s wisdom by requesting that they not leave him uncertain (ne me suspensum incertumque dimittas). This appeal to their responsibility and knowledge strengthens his persuasion by making the recipient feel compelled to provide a decisive answer.”

Additional Notes:

The explanation does not need to be in separate sentences. The Latin citation and the explanation of it can be contained in a single sentence (or multiple sentences).

CLP000005_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and translations or to score the response.

The student must correctly translate all words in a given segment to receive credit for that segment.

Note: The passage is segmented in such a way as to achieve a balance of easy, medium, and hard segments. Glosses are added to the passage only in order to make a given segment easier, so uncommon words in harder segments will not necessarily be glossed.

Note: The model translation provided below is merely a suggestion of how the passage might accurately be translated. Teachers should use their discretion in accepting alternative translations of any given segment.

Model Translation:

But twin snakes flee to the highest (part of the) temples by gliding and they head for the citadel of savage Minerva, and they are covered under the feet and the curve of the shield of the goddess. Then truly a new fear enters through the trembling chests of everyone, and they say that deserving Laocoon paid for his crime.

o.d:
The response does not accurately translate this segment.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • But the snakes flee

  • And the serpents escape

The response accurately translates this segment.

Responses that do not earn this point.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Rather than losing his cool at the possibility of an encounter with a ghost, Athenodorus sets his mind to writing in order to avoid imagining something happening that isn’t (ipse ad scribendum…metus fingeret). In this we see his calmness on display.”

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) and sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit). By doing this, he selflessly puts himself right where he expects the ghost to appear, while sparing everyone else the fright.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Provide no explanation of the cited Latin.

  • Do not address the prompt in the explanation.

  • Rely on incorrect assumptions about the Latin citation in the explanation.

The response provides one incomplete explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus busies himself with writing in order to avoid getting unnecessarily afraid (ipse ad scibendum…metus fingeret). The fact that he knows ghosts are only ‘empty’ (inanes) figments shows his bravery.”

Additional Notes:

EXH000003_Part_B_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Provide one adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response BUT provide no or inadequate explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Provide one adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response AND adequately explain how the Latin citations from the provided Latin text relate to the prompt.

o.d:
The response does not provide an adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response or an adequate explanation of how the cited Latin text relates to the response.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Perpetua’s father first tries to persuade her by appealing to his actions as her father. He begs her to take pity on him, ‘if I have raised you by these hands to this bloom of age, if I have placed you ahead of all of your brothers’ (si his…fratribus tuis, lines 3-4). Her father uses their previously mutual and loving relationship as part of his argument, although the fact that he must use this prior relationship to beg her mercy highlights how strained it is now.”

  • “Perpetua’s father first pleads with her to pity him, highlighting his old age and his position as her father (Miserere…vocari, lines 2-3). Already we can see the unexpected power reversal. Her father emphasizes his feebleness in his old age and uses his position as her father not to command, but to create, sympathy.”

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Perpetua’s father first pleads with her to pity him, highlighting his old age and his position as her father (Miserere…vocari, lines 2-3). Her father uses their good relationship to try to gain sympathy.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • “Perpetua’s father first tries to persuade her by appealing to his actions as her father. He begs her to take pity on him, ‘if I have raised you by these hands to this bloom of age, if I have placed you ahead of all of your brothers’ (si his…fratribus tuis, lines 3-4).”

  • “Perpetua’s father first pleads with her to pity him, highlighting his old age and his position as her father (Miserere…vocari, lines 2-3). Her father uses their good relationship to try to gain sympathy.”

Additional Notes:

  • Paraphrase or translation of cited Latin may contain minor errors that do not detract from the response.

  • Additional citations beyond 2, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the 2 accurate citations.)

The response provides one adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text AND adequately explains how the Latin citations from the provided Latin text relate to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Perpetua’s father first tries to persuade her by appealing to his actions as her father. He begs her to take pity on him, ‘if I have raised you by these hands to this bloom of age, if I have placed you ahead of all of your brothers’ (si his…fratribus tuis, lines 3-4). Her father uses their previously mutual and loving relationship as part of his argument, although the fact that he must use this prior relationship to beg her mercy highlights how strained it is now.”

  • “Perpetua’s father first pleads with her to pity him, highlighting his old age and his position as her father (Miserere…vocari, lines 2-3). Already we can see the unexpected power reversal. Her father emphasizes his feebleness in his old age and uses his position as her father not to command, but to create, sympathy.”

Additional Notes:

  • Additional citations beyond 2, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the 2 accurate citations.)

EXH000003_Part_B_rubric_category_2.ti: Part B (iii) Latin citation AND Explanation: Second example
EXH000003_Part_B_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Provide one adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response BUT provides no or inadequate explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Reponses that earn two points:

  • Provide one adequate Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response AND adequately explains how the Latin citations from the provided Latin text relate to the prompt.

o.d:
The response provides no explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “After her father’s speech, Perpetua notes that he said these things ‘as her father, out of his own devotion’ (quasi pater pro sua pietate, line 8). Perpetua explicitly recognizes and seems to appreciate that her father says what he says as a result of affection for her, although she seems equally unpersuaded by it.”

  • “Perpetua’s father demands that Perpetua think of her family and how her actions affect them (Aspice fratres…poterit, lines 5-6). If he earlier appealed to the, at least previously, good relationship between her and himself, he now highlights her potential selfishness and the strain she now places on her relationship with him and her whole family.”

  • “Perpetua’s father ends his speech by ordering her to change her mind, so that she does not get them all killed or, at least, socially demoted (Depone…passa, lines 6-7). While her father tries to take the approach as the paterfamilias of ordering her to do something, his actual powerlessness is immediately noted in his warning that she is the one with the power to destroy them and ruin them socially.

EXH000003_Part_B_rubric_category_3.ti: Part B (iv) Contextual or Stylistic Information
EXH000003_Part_B_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Include contextual or stylistic information that is relevant to the provided Latin text BUT does not explain how this information relates to the prompt.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Include contextual or stylistic information that is relevant to the provided Latin text AND explains how this information relates to the prompt.

o.d:
The response provides no explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Perpetua’s father uses anaphora in his speech, repeating the imperative ‘aspice’ (‘look at!) three times in lines 5-6. Her father’s repetition highlights Perpetua’s selfishness as it draws particular attention to each family member and the effect Perpetua’s actions will have on them, that she ignores.”

  • “As the paterfamilias of the family, Perpetua’s father would have had complete power over his family. Yet the father’s begging from his daughter to spare him and her family misfortune and his debasing actions (such as kissing her hands in line 8) represent a reversal of this power, now seemingly in Perpetua’s hands.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Perpetua’s father’s speech involves multiple instances of parallelism, such as the repetition of the ‘if’ statements in lines 2-4 (si…si…si).”

  • “Perpetua’s father uses anaphora in his speech, repeating the imperative ‘aspice’ (‘look at!’) three times in lines 5-6.”

  • “As the paterfamilias of the family, Perpetua’s father would have had complete power over his family.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Do not include any contextual or stylistic information relevant to the text.

  • Include contextual or stylistic information, but it is not accurate.

  • Include contextual or stylistic information, but it is not relevant to the response or prompt.

  • “As the paterfamilias of the family, Perpetua’s father would have had complete power over his family.”

Additional Notes:

  • Examples of contextual or stylistic information include but are not limited to:

    • Information about the life and works of the author

    • Information about the larger work from which the passage is drawn

    • Information about the passage’s genre

    • Reference to substantive elements of style, such as simile or metaphor

    • Reference to Roman values

    • Reference to Greco-Roman mythology and legend

  • An adequate explanation may make incorrect inferences based on the contextual or stylistic information provided.

  • If the contextual or stylistic information on its own is not obviously relevant, a point will not be awarded unless its relevancy is explained.

FT540741_rubric_category_0.s:
Translation

“O queen, to whom Jupiter has granted to found a new city, and to restrain the haughty tribes with justice, we, unhappy Trojans, carried over all seas by the winds, beg you: keep the unspeakable fires away from our ships; spare a pious race, and look more closely at our affairs.”

15 points total: 1 point for each segment with acceptable translation.


1. O regina
O regina: (Oh/O) queen [O need not be translated, but regina must be construed as vocative]


2. cui Iuppiter dedit
to whom Jupiter (has) granted/given, whom Jupiter (has) allowed/permitted


3. condere novam urbem

to found/establish/build a new city/(walled) town

4. iustitiaque frenare

with/by means of justice/equity/righteousness [must be construed as ablative of means]
-que: and
frenare: (to) restrain/bridle/govern/keep in check [to may be omitted if used previously to translate condere]

5. superbas gentes

(the) haughty/proud tribes/races/peoples/nations [must be construed as direct object of frenare]


6. Troes miseri
wretched/unhappy/miserable/unfortunate Trojans

7. vecti ventis

carried/borne/conveyed, having traveled/sailed ventis: by/on the winds


8. maria omnia

over/on/across all seas [must be translated as a prepositional phrase if

vecti is translated as passive (e.g., “carried”), may be translated as direct object if vecti is translated as transitive (e.g., “having traveled”)]


9. te oramus

we beg/implore/beseech you


10. prohibe

hold back/keep away/keep off/ward off/avert [must be construed as

imperative]


11. infandos ignes

unspeakable/abominable/atrocious fires [must be rendered as plural]


12. a navibus

from the ships


13. parce pio generi

spare/be sparing to [must be construed as imperative]
pio generi: a pious/dutiful/devout race/people/nation


14. et aspice propius

and

aspice: look upon/look at/regard/consider [must be construed as imperative]

propius: more closely


15. res nostras

our affairs/circumstances [must be construed as object of aspice]

FT541035_rubric_category_0.s:
Translation

When the Helvetii have been informed of his arrival, they send to him the most eminent (men) of the state as ambassadors, of which embassy Nammeius and Verucloetius occupied the chief position, to say that they have it in mind to make a journey through the province without any mischief.

15 points total: 1point for each segment and acceptable translation.

1. Ubi Helvetii
Ubi: when Helvetii: the Helvetians, the Helvetii [must be construed as subject]

2. de eius adventu

about, concerning, of eius: his, of him [must be construed as modifying adventu] adventu: (the) arrival/approach [must be construed as object of de]

3. certiores facti sunt

were/have been made more certain, were/have been informed/apprised [may be construed as past perfect (“had been”) only if mittunt is translated as simple past (“sent”)]

4. ad eum mittunt

ad eum: to him mittunt: sent/sends

5. legatos nobilissimos

(as)ambassadors/envoys/emissaries/legates/deputies nobilissimos: noblest/most noble/very noble/most eminent/most famous (men) [must be construed as superlative; may be construed as adjective modifying legatos or as substantive in apposition with legatos]

6. civitatis

of the city/state/nation/tribe, the city’s/state’s/nation’s/tribe’s

7. cuius legationis

of which/this/whose embassy/legation

8. principem locum

the chief/first/principal place/position/rank [must be construed as direct object]

9. Nammeius et Verucloetius obtinebant

Nammeius and Verucloetius [must be construed as subject] obtinebant: held/possessed/occupied, were holding/possessing/occupying

10. qui dicerent

qui dicerent: (in order) to say, so that they might say, who were to/might/should/would say [must be construed as expressing purpose]

11. sibi esse

that it was/is . . . their (mind)/for them, that they had/have (it) [must be construed as past if mittunt is construed as past, present if mittunt is construed as present]

12. in animo

in (their) mind(s)

13. sine ullo maleficio

without any misdeed/offense/misbehavior/mischief

14. iter facere

to make a journey/march, to march

15. per provinciam

through/across the province

FT541601_rubric_category_0.s:
The student response can earn up to 9 points, one half-point for each segment, rounding up to the next highest integer:

1. obstipui: I was stunned / struck dumb; I stood amazed

2. subiit ... subiit: came to (my) mind / rose up / came upon (me) / occurred (to me) [must be past tense]

3. imago: the / an image / likeness [must be subject of subiit]

cari genitoris: of (my / the) dear father / parent; (my) father’s / parent’s [must be construed with imago]

4. ut: as / when vidi: I saw [must be past tense]

5. regem: the king [must be direct object of vidi]

aequaevum: of the same / equal / like age [must modify regem]

6. vitam: (his) life [must be direct object of exhalentem]

exhalentem: breathing out / exhaling [must modify regem and must be present tense]

7. crudeli vulnere: by / because of / from / with the / a cruel / savage / merciless wound

8. deserta Creusa: Creusa (having been) abandoned [must be subject of subiit]

9. et direpta domus: and the house (having been) plundered / pulled to pieces / ruined / destroyed [must be subject of subiit]

10. et casus: and the misfortune / chance / fate [must be subject of subiit]

parvi Iuli: of small / little Iulus / Ascanius; small / little Iulus’s / Ascanius’s [must be construed with casus]

11. respicio: I look back / around [may be past tense if lustro is also rendered as a past tense]

et lustro: and I survey / seek / review [may be past tense if respicio is also rendered as a past

tense]

12. quae copia: what / which force(s) / band / troop(s) [must be subject of sit]

sit: is [may be past tense if respicio and lustro are also rendered as historical presents; may be

plural if copia is rendered as plural]

13. circum me: around / about me

14. omnes: (they) all / everyone

defessi: tired / exhausted / having lost heart [must modify omnes]

deseruere: (have) abandoned (me) [may be pluperfect if respicio and lustro are rendered as past tense; may be singular with appropriate rendering of omnes]

15. et misere: and (have) sent [may be pluperfect if respicio and lustro are rendered as past tense; may be singular with appropriate rendering of omnes]

saltu: with / in a leap / jump; by jumping

16. aut dedere: or (have) given / surrendered [may be pluperfect if respicio and lustro are rendered as past tense; may be singular with appropriate rendering of omnes]

ignibus: to the fire(s) [must be dative indirect]

17. corpora: (their) bodies [must be direct object of misere and / or dedere]

aegra: their sick / weary [must modify the direct object of dedere]

18. ad terram: to the ground / earth / land

Full translation:

I was stunned; the image of my dear father came (to mind), as I saw the king of similar age breathing out hislife from the cruel wound, Creusa (having been) abandoned came over (me), and the plundered house and themisfortune of little Iulus. I look back and survey what force(s) there is (are) around me. All, exhausted, havedeserted (me) and sent their weary bodies to the ground in a leap or given them to the fires.

The student response is scored on a 6-point scale:

6

This is an excellent, well-organized essay. It makes liberal use of specific, appropriate references from the Latin text throughout the passage, properly cited. These references support the discussion of the ways in which Vergil creates sympathy for Marcellus and why the student thinks he does so. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of Latin citations are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5

This is a good, strong essay with a discerning discussion of the ways in which Vergil creates sympathy for Marcellus and why the student thinks he does so. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or well developed as a “6” or not quite as well supported with textual references from throughout the passage. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the essay reflects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

4

This is an adequate essay with some accurate discussion of the ways in which Vergil creates sympathy for Marcellus and why the student thinks he does so. The discussion may be uneven with emphasis only on the ways Vergil creates sympathy or only on why he does so; or it may be more descriptive than analytical. The Latin references, although perhaps scanty, are specific, accurate, and relevant.

3

This is a limited response that lacks adequate discussion of the ways in which Vergil creates sympathy for Marcellus and why the student thinks he does so or that deals only with the ways Vergil creates sympathy or only with why he does so. The answer tends to rely on description. In general, the Latin support is weak, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. Alternately, the student may write a good essay reflecting knowledge of the passage but fail to cite any Latin to support the answer.

2

The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague or weak discussion. Statements may be very general or irrelevant to the question. The student shows only limited comprehension of the Latin cited or fails to cite any Latin at all.

1

The student understands the question but presents no meaningful discussion derived from the passage. FT542108_rubric_category_0.s:
The student response can earn up to 9 points total: one half-point for each segment, rounding up to the next highest integer.

1. Laocoon: Laocoon [must be subject of mactabat]

mactabat: was sacriﬁcing / killing / slaughtering / slaying [must be rendered as imperfect or simple past]

2. ductus: (having been) chosen / selected / led / drawn / picked [must modify Laocoon]

sorte: by lot / oracular response / luck / fate / chance

3. sacerdos: (as) priest [must refer to Laocoon]

Neptuno: to / by / for Neptune; of Neptune

4. sollemnes: solemn / ceremonial / sacred / customary / sacriﬁcial / holy [must modify aras]

ad aras: at / near / to / toward / by / before the altar(s) [may be singular]

5. taurum ingentem: a large / huge / immense / massive / giant / enormous / great bull [must be direct object of mactabat]

6. ecce: behold / lo / look / see!

autem: however / on the other hand / and in fact / now / but / and then indeed / moreover

gemini … angues: twin / two snakes / serpents [must be subject of incumbunt]

7. a Tenedo: from Tenedos

8. per alta: through / over / across the sea / deep / depths / water(s) [may be singular]

tranquilla: calm / peaceful / still / placid / gentle / quiet / tranquil [must modify alta]

9. horresco: I shudder / tremble / bristle / shiver

referens: relating / referring (to) / recalling (it) / remembering / bringing back / telling / speakingof / recounting / retelling / saying / mentioning / bearing (it) back

10. immensis orbibus: with / in huge / immense / massive / large / big / giant coils / circles

11. incumbunt: lie / press / lean / glide / incline / fall / skim / recline / bear down [may be past tense if tendunt and superantare also past tense]

pelago: on / upon the sea / deep / water / ocean [must be construed with incumbunt]

12. pariterque: and together / side by side / at the same time / equally / in pairs

tendunt: direct their course / proceed / strain / strive / stretch / aim for / head for / make way [may be past tense if incumbunt and superant are also past tense]

13. ad litora: to / for the shore(s) / coast(s) [may be singular]

14. pectora: breasts / chests [must be subject of superant or arrecta (sunt)]

quorum: their / whose / of which / of whom

15. arrecta: upright / erect / (having been) raised up / elevated / reared up / uplifted / held up; (having) (a)risen; are / were raised up / elevated / reared up [may modify pectora or sunt may be supplied rather than making pectora the subject of superant]

16. inter ﬂuctus: amid / among / between the waves / billows / swells / water(s)

17. iubaeque sanguineae: and bloody / blood red / crimson crests / necks / manes [must be subject of superant]

18. superant: rise above (over) / surmount / overcome / tower above / overwhelm / surpass / conquer / overtop [may be

past tense if incumbunt and tendunt are also past tense]

undas: the waves / swells [must be construed with superant]

Translation

Laocoon, (having been) chosen by lot priest of Neptune, was sacriﬁcing a huge bull at the ceremonial altar(s). And then—behold!—two snakes from Tenedos (Relating [it] I shudder) through the calm deep, with huge coils, press upon the sea andtogether strive for the shore; their breasts, elevated amid the waves, and their bloody crests rise above the waves

The student response is scored on a 6-point scale:

6

This is an excellent, well-organized essay. It makes liberal use of speciﬁc, appropriate references from the Latin text throughout the passage, all properly cited. The essay discusses the effect that the mixture of references to the past, present, and future in the Sibyl’s prophecy has on the reader. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of features selected are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5

This is a good, strong essay with a discerning discussion of the effect that the mixture of references to the past, present, and future in the Sibyl’s prophecy has on the reader. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or as well developed as a 6, or not quite as well supported with textual references from throughout the passage. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear conﬁdent, and the essay reﬂects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

4

This is an adequate essay with some accurate discussion of the effect that the mixture of references to the past, present, and future in the Sibyl’s prophecy has on the reader. The discussion may be more descriptive than analytical or may deal fully with the Sibyl’s prophecy and only in a general way with the effect on the reader. The Latin references, although perhaps scanty, are speciﬁc, accurate, and relevant.

FT543341_rubric_category_0.s:
This question is scored on a 6-point scale:

6

An excellent, well-organized essay which includes a convincing discussion of Dido’s psychological/emotional conﬂict by making use of references from the text to her past, present, and future. The discussion contains liberal use of speciﬁc, appropriate references from the Latin text, with accurate translation or paraphrase, which support the analysis. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. A strong thesis underlies and ties the essay together.

5

A very good essay which includes a fairly persuasive discussion of Dido‘s psychological/emotional conﬂict. A number of references from the text to Dido’s past, present, and future are used to support the analysis.

4

A passing score: a "bare bones" response which contains an adequate but superficial discussion of Dido‘s psychological/emotional conﬂict. Essay tends to be descriptive rather than analytical. References are made to Dido’s past, present, and future. These may be scanty, not optimally chosen and/or unevenly discussed. Or, there is a good discussion of two of the time periods, with good Latin support.

3

Essay merely paraphrases the passage without discussion of how the text conveys Dido‘s confusion. Or, there is a fairly good discussion of Dido’s conﬂict without support from the text. References to the time periods are incomplete or unsupported by references from the text.

2

An effort is made to discuss Dido’s confusion, but Latin support is sparse, incorrect, and/or ineffectual. Some correct information is given.

1

Disorganized effort at discussion of Dido‘s confusion, based largely on information given in the question. Textual references (if any) show no indication of an understanding of the Latin. Some bit of correct information must be given beyond what is given in the question.

0

An answer which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect.

FT543344_rubric_category_0.s:
This question is scored on a 4-point scale.

4

A completely correct account of how both Laocoon and Cassandra suffer, and a clear connection between their prophetic gift and their deaths. How they suffer may include:

1.) They both die, but the death of Laocoon must be explained; they are both scorned by the Trojans; no one believes them (though they speak the truth).

2.) Laocoon (and his sons) are killed by snakes (sea monsters), and Cassandra is carried off (eventually killed) by the Greeks, or Cassandra is dragged from the temple by the Greeks.

It is acceptable for students to say that Laocoon is killed by the Greeks, though he is technically killed by the snakes, because the snakes symbolize Greek treachery.

Any allusion to the nature or manner of Cassandra’s death should be ignored if inaccurate.

All that students must say to receive full credit for the Cassandra portion of 1 is that she told the truth but no one believed her.

3

Accurate observations about both characters (except Cassandra’s death). Connection between their prophetic gift and their deaths not so clear.

2

One character is discussed adequately.

1

Generally poor discussion of one or both characters. The answer cannot come strictly from the question

0

Student provides no correct answer

The student response can earn up to 3 points.

A 3-point answer must contain the following elements, expressed in one or more sentences: The name Marcellus must be given; the relationship to Augustus must be stated; Marcellus’ premature death must be mentioned.

A full answer could include the following:

Adopted by Augustus as his heir and successor apparent and given an inside track for political advancement, Marcellus died prematurely at the age of 19 in 23 B.C, his death being universally lamented. Octavia is said to have swooned with grief at Vergil's reading of this passage and later to have rewarded the poet for his tribute.

FT543349_rubric_category_0.s:
egregium forma iuvenem et fulgentibus armis

“a young man outstanding in appearance and gleaming armor”

A total of 4 points is possible, one point per the following:

A iuvenis is a young person, generally between the ages of 20 and 40. Accept “young man,”

“young person”, or “youth.” Readers accepted, but very reluctantly, “juvenile” or “boy.”


egregium. Readers accepted “extraordinary, distinguished, surpassing, excellent, eminent, outstanding, select, marvelous, exceptional, singular, illustrious,” and the like, but did not accept “egregious.”

The ablatives could be translated variously as “in, with, by, in respect to, because of, as to.”

For forma, readers accepted “appearance, looks, ﬁgure, shape, feature(s)” or “beauty, form.”

For armis, readers accepted “armor, arms, weapons, implements of war.” For fulgentibus, readers accepted “shining, bright, gleaming, ﬂashing, dazzling, glistening, illustrious, glorious.”

egregium. Readers accepted “extraordinary, distinguished, surpassing, excellent, eminent,
outstanding, select, marvelous, exceptional, singular, illustrious,” and the like, but did not
accept “egregious.”


The ablatives could be translated variously as “in, with, by, in respect to, because of, as to.”


For forma, readers accepted “appearance, looks, ﬁgure, shape, feature(s)” or “beauty, form.”


For armis, readers accepted “armor, arms, weapons, implements of war.” For fulgentibus, readers accepted “shining, bright, gleaming, ﬂashing, dazzling, glistening, illustrious, glorious.”

FT543349_rubric_category_1.s:
The student response can earn up to 3 points:

1 point for identiﬁcation

2 points for sentences of description

(2 points for full description, 1 point for adequate)

Students included the following young persons; the most appropriate were those who died a premature death in Books 7-12: Pallas, son of Evander, befriended by Aeneas, slain by Turnus. (Book 10)

Euryalus, young Trojan warrior killed while attempting to carry a message to Aeneas regarding the Latin attack on the Trojan camp. (Book 9)

Lausus, son of Mezentius, killed by Aeneas while attempting to rescue his father. (Book 10)


Camilla, warrior maiden, ally of Turnus, and cavalry leader killed in battle. (Book 11)


Turnus, prince of the Rutulians, killed by Aeneas. (Book 12)


A case could be made for Ascanius (Book 9) as well as for Aeneas himself, on the basis of their physical appearance and their armor. (Book 8)


Mezentius and Nisus were acceptable as egregium . . . armis.

FT543830_rubric_category_0.s:
The student response is scored on a 6-point scale:

6

An excellent, focused, well-organized essay. The discussion makes liberal use of speciﬁc, appropriate references from the Latin throughout the passage, properly cited, to discuss Vergil‘s portrayal of Aeneas‘ hesitant or inconsistent behavior in the ﬁnal scene of the poem. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of features selected are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5

A good, strong essay with discerning discussion about Vergil‘s portrayal of Aeneas’ hesitant or inconsistent behavior. The discussion is either not so sophisticated, balanced, or well-developed as above or not quite as well-supported with textual references throughout the passage. The references to the Latin that do appear are properly cited and seem conﬁdent, and the essay reﬂects more than a casual familiarity with the ﬁnal scene of the Aeneid.

4

An adequate essay with limited discussion of Aeneas’ complex behavior. The discussion may be uneven and may emphasize one aspect of Aeneas‘ behavior more than another, or it may be limited in discussing the contrasting aspects in Vergil‘s portrayal of Aeneas. The Latin references, although perhaps scanty, are nevertheless speciﬁc, accurate, and relevant.

3

A limited response which may identify one aspect of Aeneas’ behavior, but not contrast it, or may discuss only one aspect in depth but ignore any other. In general, the Latin support is weak, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. The response tends to rely on mere translation. Alternatively, the student may write a good essay reﬂecting a thorough recollection of the passage, but cite no Latin to support the answer.

2

The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague or faulty discussion. The response shows very limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or Latin may not be cited at all. Statements demonstrate a flawed recollection of the passage or are very general or irrelevant to the question.

1

The student understands the question but is unable to write any meaningful discussion. Although no substantive argument is present, the response does contain some correct information relevant to the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin of the passage or demonstrates a complete misunderstanding. The answer may contain either no Latin or individual words randomly selected.

0

A response which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect, or which merely restates the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin in context. —— A blank space or off-task answer (drawings, personal letters, etc.)

2 points maximum

1 point - for citing the appropriate Latin.

1 point - for giving an accurate translation. Any of the following answers are possible:

sola (ne): alone

maerens: grieving, unhappy

carpere: will you be consumed (consume yourself)?

[Translation must reflect the correct person and tense; no translation point if rendered as an infinitive.]

Any combination of the various elements in line 2 is acceptable, but perpetua iuventa by itself would not qualify as a consequence.

nec dulces natos.....noris?: will you not know sweet children?

Veneris nec praemia noris?: will you not know the rewards of love?

N.B. The verb noris need not appear in the answer.

FT555400_rubric_category_0.s:
10 points maximum

Translation: And just as in a great crowd often when a riot has arisen and the common rabble rages in (their) minds, and now torches and rocks fly, the fury furnishes the arms; then if by chance they saw some man weighty by his devotion and merits, they are silent and stand with pricked up ears.

1 point for each of the following groups of words:

Ac veluti magno in populo

cum saepe coorta est seditio

saevitque animis ignobile vulgus

iamque faces et saxa volant

furor arma ministrat

tum...si forte....conspexere

....virum quem

pietate gravem ac meritis

silent

arrectisque auribus astant

Acceptable translations:

  • Ac veluti: (And) as, (And) just as

  • cum saepe coorta est: when as often happens, occurs, arises, breaks out (passive is not acceptable, but the present or past tense is acceptable)

  • seditio: sedition, riot, revolt, unrest, strife

  • saevit: rages, be furious, burns

  • ignobile: base, ignoble, unknown, common, with ignoble mind

  • vulgus: common people, crowd, mob, rabble

  • faces: torches, firebrand, fires, flames

  • ministrat: provides, serves, furnishes, manages, supplies, administers

  • conspexere: they see, they have seen, they would see (infinitive translation unacceptable)

  • pietate: sense of duty, devotion, patriotism, pietas (not piety), faithfulness

  • gravem: heavy, weighty, burdened, distinguished, serious, notable

  • meritis: merits, faithful service, duties, responsibilities

  • virum quem: some man, a man, any man, one man

  • silent: are silent, become silent

  • astant: stand, await, stand (by), remain; listen also acceptable

N.B. Words must be translated correctly within the context of the passage; for example, a direct object in Latin needs to appear as a direct object in the translation. A correct translation of a word without regard for how it actually appears in the Latin is not acceptable.

In order to award some credit for a translation which was slightly misconstrued but in which the student showed a reasonable grasp of the Latin, the faculty consultants read the following phrases holistically: Ac...populo, sum saepe....seditio, saevitque....vulgus, tum....si forte....conspexere,....virum quem pietate gravem ac meritis

  • cum saepe coorta est: when as often happens, occurs, arises, breaks out (passive is not acceptable, but the present or past tense is acceptable)

  • seditio: sedition, riot, revolt, unrest, strife

  • saevit: rages, be furious, burns

  • ignobile: base, ignoble, unknown, common, with ignoble mind

  • vulgus: common people, crowd, mob, rabble

  • faces: torches, firebrand, fires, flames

  • ministrat: provides, serves, furnishes, manages, supplies, administers

  • conspexere: they see, they have seen, they would see (infinitive translation unacceptable)

  • pietate: sense of duty, devotion, patriotism, pietas (not piety), faithfulness

  • gravem: heavy, weighty, burdened, distinguished, serious, notable

  • meritis: merits, faithful service, duties, responsibilities

  • virum quem: some man, a man, any man, one man

  • silent: are silent, become silent

  • astant: stand, await, stand (by), remain; listen also acceptable

N.B. Words must be translated correctly within the context of the passage; for example, a direct object in Latin needs to appear as a direct object in the translation. A correct translation of a word without regard for how it actually appears in the Latin is not acceptable.

In order to award some credit for a translation which was slightly misconstrued but in which the student showed a reasonable grasp of the Latin, the faculty consultants read the following phrases holistically: Ac...populo, sum saepe....seditio, saevitque....vulgus, tum....si forte....conspexere,....virum quem pietate gravem ac meritis

Student response earns four of the available points.

10 points maximum

FT555425_rubric_category_0.s:
3 points maximum

2 points - student correctly identifies a specific event in Books 7-12

1 point - vague or flawed reference to events in Books 7-12

NB: Urbem Latini may not be identified as the city which Aeneas founds in the future, but it may be identified as the "Latin city"; the marriage with Lavinia, the founding of a city, the merging of peoples may earn 1 point but not 2.

1 point. Student articulates well the connection between Laurentes populos or urbem Latini and the specific events s/he describes from Books 7-12. For full credit the student must correctly understand that Laurentes populos refers to the Italian tribes fighting against Aeneas or that urbem Latini means the city of Latinus. Readers looked for specificity, the link between the phrases and the 7-12 event(s) cited, and whether the answer was so flawed as to contradict itself. Events most often cited: the betrothal of Lavinia, Aeneas' war with the Latins, and the defeat of Turnus.

FT555508_rubric_category_0.s:
4 points maximum

2 points (1 point per item) for appropriate Latin correctly translated. The student must "write out and translate." The response may be incorporated into a discussion.

As a minimum, bolded words must be included in any two of the following possible responses:

  • Parce metu
    Spare (your) fear

  • manent immota tuorum fata tibi
    the fates of your people remain fixed for you

  • cernes urbem et promissa Lavini moenia
    you will see a city and the promised walls of Lavinium

    It is permissible to use only half of this clause.

    • cernes urbem
      you will see a city

    • cernes...promissa Lavini moenia
      you will see the promised walls of Lavinium

    but since both objects of cernes refer to the one city of Lavinium, only one point will be awarded for either one of both parts of this clause.

    If the student incorrectly translates Lavini as "of Lavinia" or "Lavinian," the translation is not ruined provided the student clearly demonstrates that the future city is meant.

  • sublimemque feres ad sidera caeli magnanimum Aenean
    you will carry great-souled Aeneas aloft to the stars of heaven

  • neque me sententia vertit
    opinion does not sway me (no thought has changed my mind)

    This item is Jupiter's response to Venus' question in lines 237: quae te genitor sententia vertit? (What thought, father, has changed your mind?)

2 points for explaining "why these remarks are reassuring."

2 points for a full and accurate explanation which explains why these remarks are reassuring and which makes reference to specific events in the Aeneid.

1 point for a correct but less specific or detailed answer.

FT555521_rubric_category_0.s:
6 - An excellent well-organized short essay which uses analysis of the Latin text to demonstrate how Iarbas' speech reflects his contempt for both Aeneas' culture and his behavior, and also describes accurately the parallel nature of the following triangular relationships: Paris-Helen-Menelaus, Aeneas-Dido-Iarbas, and Aeneas-Lavinia-Turnus.

5 - A good, strong short essay which demonstrates how Iarbas' speech expresses contempt for both Aeneas' culture and his behavior and also describes accurately the various triangular relationships. Either not as sophisticated or well-developed a discussion as above or not as well supported with textual references as above. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the discussion reflects more than casual familiarity with Books 7-12.

4 - An adequate response which demonstrates, if only in a limited way, how Iarbus' speech reflects his contempt for both Aeneas' culture and his behavior, and identifies the comparison in Books 7-12 of Aeneas to Paris. Reference to the Latin, although it may be scanty, is specific, accurate, and relevant. The response may tend to be more descriptive than analytical.

3 - The response either gives a full discussion of the speech of Iarbas or draws the Paris comparison superficially, but does not address both adequately. -OR- The response discusses fully the speech of Iarbas alone with appropriate Latin support or the response discusses fully the Paris comparison and refers to specific events in Books 7-12.

2 - The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague, mediocre, or faulty discussion with no attempt at real analysis of Iarbas' speech. The student shows very limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or Latin may not be cited at all. Statements are very general (possibly just a restatement of the question) or irrelevant to the question.

1 - The student understands the question but is not able to write any meaningful discussion. Although the discussion of one or both passages may be very weak, the response does contain some correct information. The student may offer a collection of information which is incoherent or irrelevant to the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin of the passages, or demonstrates a complete misunderstanding.

0 - An answer which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect.

–– A blank space or off-task answer (drawings, personal letters, etc.)

FT555592_rubric_category_0.s:
10 points maximum

Shaken by these things, Dido was preparing flight and comrades. They come together, to whom there was either a cruel hatred of the tyrant or a sharp fear; they seize ships which [were] by chance prepared and load [them] with gold. The riches of covetous Pygmalion are carried on the sea; a woman [was] the leader of the action.

1 point for each group:

his commota...Dido

fugam...sociosque parabat

conveniunt...quibus...erat

aut odium crudele tyranni aut metus acer

naves...corripiunt

quae forte paratae

onerantque auro

portantur...pelago

avari Pygmalionis opes

dux femina facti

commota: moved, roused, aroused, alarmed, shaken, disturbed, troubled, upset, affected.

fugam: flight, exile, escape.

socios: comrades, allies, followers, companions.

parabat: prepared, collected (zeugma), began to make preparations for, began to prepare.

conveniunt: come together, assemble (those who assemble...).

quibus: to whom, for whom.

odium: hatred, hate, enmity.

crudele: cruel, bloody, fierce, ruthless, savage, violent (may be considered a transferred epithet and agree with tyranni).

metus: fear, dread, anxiety.

acer: sharp, fierce.

naves: ships, boats, fleet.

corripiunt: seize, snatch (up).

forte: by chance, accidentally, happened to be, luckily.

quae: (must be expressed)

paratae: prepared, made ready, are ready, are prepared.

onerant: load.

auro: gold, treasure, riches, money (must be expressed as an ablative).

pelago: sea, waves (as ablative or dative of direction).

avari: covetous, greedy, grasping.

opes: riches, wealth, resources (military, economic, etc.), power.

dux: leader, guide, chieftain.

facti: deed, undertaking, exploit, enterprise, expedition (must be rendered as a noun).

Present tense verbs may be translated as historical present, but the student must be consistent throughout the passage.

o.d:
Student response earns none of the available points.

commota: moved, roused, aroused, alarmed, shaken, disturbed, troubled, upset, affected.

fugam: flight, exile, escape.

socios: comrades, allies, followers, companions.

parabat: prepared, collected (zeugma), began to make preparations for, began to prepare.

conveniunt: come together, assemble (those who assemble...).

quibus: to whom, for whom.

odium: hatred, hate, enmity.

crudele: cruel, bloody, fierce, ruthless, savage, violent (may be considered a transferred epithet and agree with tyranni).

metus: fear, dread, anxiety.

paratae: prepared, made ready, are ready, are prepared.

dux: leader, guide, chieftain.

facti: deed, undertaking, exploit, enterprise, expedition (must be rendered as a noun).

The riches of covetous Pygmalion are carried on the sea; a woman [was] the leader of the action.

FT555594_rubric_category_0.s:
6 - An excellent, well-organized essay which analyzes how the speaker conveys his anger. The discussion makes liberal use of specific, appropriate references from the Latin text, properly cited, to support the analysis and the argument. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of features selected are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5 - A good, strong essay which, in a fairly discerning discussion, analyzes how the speaker conveys his anger. The response correctly identifies the speaker, the listeners, and the situation. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or well-developed as above or not quite as well supported with textual references as above. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the essay reflects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

4 - An adequate response which contained a limited discussion of how the speaker conveys his anger. The discussion may be uneven or may be more descriptive than analytical. The Latin references, although perhaps scanty, are specific, accurate, and relevant.

3 - The response contains an adequate discussion of the general content of the passage. In general, the Latin support is weak, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. The answer tends to rely on description. Alternatively, the student may write a good essay reflecting a knowledge of the passage, but no Latin is cited to support the answer.

2 - The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague, mediocre, or faulty discussion with no real attempt to analyze how the speaker conveys his anger. The student shows very limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or Latin may not be cited at all. Statements are very general (possibly just a restatement of the question) or irrelevant to the question.

1 - The student understands the question but is not able to write any meaningful discussion. Although no substantive argument is presented, the response does contain some correct information. The response may consist of a collection of information which is incoherent or irrelevant to the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin of the passage or demonstrates a complete misunderstanding.

0 - An answer which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect.

–– A blank space or off-task answer (drawings, personal letters, etc.)

FT555756_rubric_category_0.s:
9 points maximum

Translation:

The fateful machine climbs the walls, teeming with arms. Boys and unmarried girls sing sacred (songs) around (it) and rejoice to touch the rope with their hand(s); it approaches and, threatening, glides in(to) the middle of the city. O fatherland, O Ilium home of the gods and walls of the Dardanians renowned in war! Four times it stopped on the very threshold of the gate and four times the arms gave a sound from (its) belly.

One-half point for each group, rounding up to the next higher integer:

  1. fatalis machina

  2. scandit muros

  3. feta armis

  4. pueri innuptaeque puellae

  5. circum...sacra canunt

  6. gaudent contingere

  7. funemque manu

  8. illa subit

  9. minans

  10. mediaeque...inlabitur urbi

  11. O patria O divum domus Ilium

  12. et...moenia Dardanidum

  13. incluta bello

  14. quater...quater

  15. substitit

  16. ipso in limine portae

  17. atque utero sonitum

  18. arma dedere

(*general note: the historical present may be acceptable if used consistently)

*scandit: climbs, mounts, ascends, scales
fatalis: fated, fateful, deadly, destined, fatal, of death, of fate
machina: machine, device, contraption, engine (must be subject of scandit)
muros: wall(s), rampart(s) (must be object of scandit)
feta: teeming, pregnant, filled, full of, stuffed (must modify machina)
armis: with arms, with weapons; with armed men, soldiers (by metonomy)
pueri: boys (must be subject of canunt and gaudent)
circum: around (it, horse); around, in a circle (adv.)
innuptaeque: and unwed, and unmarried, and virgin
puellae: girls, maidens (must be subject of canunt and gaudent)
sacra: sacred things, sacred songs, hymns, prayers (must be object of canunt or circum)
*canunt: sing, chant
funemque: and the rope(s), cable(s), cord(s) (must be object of contingere)
contingere: to touch, to grasp, to grab, to handle, to hold manu: with hand(s)
*gaudent: rejoice, exult, be happy, be glad, delight, be pleased
illa: it, that (machine, horse, device) (must be subject of subit)
*subit: approaches, enters, goes (up), goes forward, goes under, draws near, steals into, rises, climbs
minans: threathening, menacing, towering (must be a present participle modifying illa)
*inlabitur: glides, slides, slips, rolls
mediae urbi: in the middle (of the) city, (may be taken as a dative with minans)
O patria: O fatherland, homeland, country, native land
O Ilium: O Ilium, O Troy
domus: home, house
divum: of the gods
et...moenia: and walls, ramparts
incluta: renowned, famous, celebrated, noted
bello: in, by or for war(fare)
Dardanidum: of the Dardanains, of the Trojans; (may be expressed as an adjective)
quater: four times (must be translated correctly twice for group 14's point)
ipso: very, itself (must modify limine)
in limine: on or at the threshold, doorway, gateway, doorstep
portae: of the gate(s), of the door(s), of the entrance(s),
gate's, gates'
substitit: stopped (short), halted, stalled, stood (firm), stuck (must be perfect tense)
atque: and, and also
utero: from (in) the belly, stomach, womb, hallow cavity, underside; (may be taken as a dative with dedere)
sonitum: sound, noise, clash, clatter, clang (object of dedere)
arma: arms, weapons; armed men, soldiers (by metonomy); (must be subject of dedere)
dedere: gave, made, did give, have given (must be perfect tense)

o.d:
Student response earns none of the available points.

9 points maximum

  13. incluta bello

  14. quater...quater

  15. substitit

  16. ipso in limine portae

Translation:

The fateful machine climbs the walls, teeming with arms. Boys and unmarried girls sing sacred (songs) around (it) and rejoice to touch the rope with their hand(s); it approaches and, threatening, glides in(to) the middle of the city. O fatherland, O Ilium home of the gods and walls of the Dardanians renowned in war! Four times it stopped on the very threshold of the gate and four times the arms gave a sound from (its) belly.

FT555761_rubric_category_0.s:
6 Points maximum

6 - An excellent, well-organized essay. The discussion makes liberal use of specific, appropriate references from the Latin text throughout the passage, properly cited, to discuss Jupiter’s characterization of Rome’s future. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of features selected are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5 - A good, strong essay with discerning discussion of Jupiter’s characterization of Rome’s future. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or well-developed as a “6” or not quite as well-supported with textual references throughout the passage. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the essay reflects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

4 - An adequate essay about Jupiter’s characterization of Rome’s future. The discussion may be uneven or may be more descriptive than analytical. The Latin references from throughout the passage, although perhaps scanty, are specific, accurate, and relevant.

3 - A limited response which lacks an adequate discussion of Jupiter’s characterization of Rome’s future or which presents a superficial discussion of Roman history. In general, the Latin support is weak, not drawn from throughout the passage, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. The response tends to rely on description, narration, or mere translation. Alternately, the student may write a good essay reflecting knowledge of the passage, but no Latin is cited to support the answer.

2 - The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague or weak discussion. Statements are very general or irrelevant to the question. The student shows very limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or Latin may not be cited at all.

1 - The student understands the question but is unable to write any meaningful discussion derived from the passage. Although no substantive argument is presented, the response does contain some correct information relevant to the question. The student may demonstrate little or no understanding of the Latin of the passage. The answer may contain either no Latin or individual Latin words randomly selected.

0 - A response which is totally irrelevant, totally incorrect, or which merely restates the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin in context.

— A blank space or off-task answer (drawings, personal letters, etc.).

FT555780_rubric_category_0.s:
9 points total.

One half point for each group, rounding up to the next higher integer.

  1. Sunt geminae Somni portae
    Sunt: are; there are
    geminae: two/twin/double (must modify portae or be predicate adjective)
    Somni: of Sleep/of Somnus; Sleep's/Somnus' [gates...]
    portae: gates/doors (must be subject of sunt)

  2. quarum altera
    quarum altera: (the) one of which; (must contain partitive genitive)

  3. fertur cornea
    fertur: is said; is claimed; is called
    cornea: (to be [made]) of horn; horn (must be predicate adjective with fertur)

  4. qua...datur
    qua: by (means of)/through which/where (may be rendered as ablative or relative pronoun with altera as antecedent, or relative adverb)
    datur: ...is given/granted

  5. facilis...exitus
    facilis exitus: easy exit/departure (must be subject of datur)

  6. veris...umbris
    veris: true/honest/real (must modify umbris)
    umbris: to/for shades/shadows/ghosts (must be dative)

  7. altera...perfecta nitens
    altera: the other
    perfecta: (having been) made/perfected/completed/perfect/finished
    nitens: (and) shining/gleaming; perfect (and) bright

  8. candenti...elephanto
    candenti: shining/(shining/gleaming) white/bright/gleaming (must modify elephanto)
    elephanto: with/in/of ivory (may be construed with altera, perfecta, or nitens)

  9. sed...mittunt...Manes
    sed Manes: but (the) Manes/spirits of the dead/gods of the dead/Shades/Hades/souls/sleepless dead (must be subject of mittunt)
    mittunt: send/are sending (must be present tense)

  10. falsa...insomnia
    falsa...insomnia: false dreams/visions (must be direct object of mittunt)

  11. ad caelum
    ad caelum: to heaven/the sky/the upper air

  12. his...dictis
    his...dictis: with these words; these things/after these things had been said (attendant circumstance or ablative absolute)

  13. ibi tum...Anchises...prosequitur
    ibi tum: (to) there/in that place then
    Anchises...prosequitur: Anchises accompanies/escorts/follows/brings/leads (past tense accepted if emittit, secat and revisit are also past)

  14. natum...unaque Sibyllam
    natum: (his) son (must be direct object of prosequitur or emittit or both)
    unaque Sibyllam: and together (with him) the Sibyl; and also/along with/together with the Sibyl (must indicate that Sibyllam is a direct object)

  15. portaque emittit eburna
    portaque: and through/by/from/out the gate/door
    eburna: ivory/of ivory (must modify porta)
    emittit: (he) sends (them) out (past tense accepted if prosequitur, secat and revisit are also past)

  16. ille viam secat
    ille...secat: He/that one/that man cuts/makes/cuts through/cleaves/picks through (past tense accepted if prosequitur, secat and revisit are also past)
    viam: a/his/the way/road/path (must be direct object of secat)

  17. ad naves
    ad naves: to/toward the ships/boats/fleet

  18. sociosque revisit
    sociosque: (his) allies/comrades/friends/his men (must be direct object of revisit)
    revisit: and revisits/returns to/rejoins/sees again/goies back to (past tense accepted if prosequitur, emittit and secat are also past)

o.d:
Student response earns none of the available points.

FT555803_rubric_category_0.s:
6 - This is an excellent, well-organized essay. It makes liberal use of specific, appropriate references from the Latin text throughout the passage, properly cited. These references support a discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of Latin citations are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

5 - This is a good, strong essay with a discerning discussion of the Trojan's view at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or well-developed as that found in a "6" or not quite as well-supported with textual references from throughout the passage. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the essay reflects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

4 - This is an adequate essay with some accurate discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. The discussion may be uneven with emphasis only on one point of view, or it may be more descriptive than analytical. The Latin references may be scanty, but they are specific, accurate, and relevant.

3 - This is a limited response which lacks and adequate discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back, or which discusses only one point of view. The answer tends to rely on description. In general, the Latin support is weak, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. Alternatively, the student may write a good essay reflecting knowledge of the passage but fail to cite any Latin to support the answer.

2 - The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague or weak discussion. Statements may be very general or irrelevant to the question. The student may recall general information about the wooden horse or the gall of Troy but demonstrates only limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or the student may fail to cite any Latin at all.

The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin in context or demonstrates a complete misunderstanding. 1 - The student understands the question but presents no meaningful discussion derived from the passage. Although no substantive argument is presented, the response does contain some correct information relevant to the question. The student demonstrates no understanding of the Latin in context or demonstrates a complete misunderstanding. The student may fail to cite any Latin or may only provide individual Latin words, randomly selected.

2 - The student recognizes the passage but presents a vague or weak discussion. Statements may be very general or irrelevant to the question. The student may recall general information about the wooden horse or the gall of Troy but demonstrates only limited comprehension of the Latin cited, or the student may fail to cite any Latin at all.

3 - This is a limited response which lacks and adequate discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back, or which discusses only one point of view. The answer tends to rely on description. In general, the Latin support is weak, possibly misconstrued, inappropriate, and/or not properly cited. Alternatively, the student may write a good essay reflecting knowledge of the passage but fail to cite any Latin to support the answer.

4 - This is an adequate essay with some accurate discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. The discussion may be uneven with emphasis only on one point of view, or it may be more descriptive than analytical. The Latin references may be scanty, but they are specific, accurate, and relevant.

5 - This is a good, strong essay with a discerning discussion of the Trojan's view at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. The discussion is either not as sophisticated or well developed as that found in a "6" or not quite as well supported with textual references from throughout the passage. The references from the Latin, properly cited, appear confident, and the essay reflects more than casual familiarity with the passage.

6 - This is an excellent, well-organized essay. It makes liberal use of specific, appropriate references from the Latin text throughout the passage, properly cited. These references support a discussion of the Trojans' views at the time they received the wooden horse and Aeneas' view as he looks back. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. More important than the number of Latin citations are the quality and completeness of the discussion and the general coherence of the argument.

eruit: digs/tears/plucks/roots/rips/snatches (up/out); overthrows/destroys/demolishes/uproots/razes/topples/brings down/throws down/dislodges/ruins/wrecks/knocks (over)


11. totam: the whole/entire/all (the) [must modify urbem]
urbem: city [must be object of eruit]


12. a: from
sedibus: seats/foundations/bases


13. Hic: here/in this place/at this time/at this juncture/on this occasion
prima: first/as a leader/out in front [must modify Iuno]
tenet: holds/has/seizes/possesses/controls


14. Iuno: Juno
saevissima: most/very/__-est savage/raging/fierce/furious/ferocious/harsh/cruel/dire/violent [must modify Iuno]


15. Scaeas: Scaean/western/westward [not genitive] [must modify portas]
portas: gates/doors/doorways/portals
